Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the significance of a Clorox bottle claiming to kill the 2019 coronavirus before it was developed.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to prove that the Clorox bottle made such a claim.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the existence of a Clorox bottle claiming to kill the 2019 coronavirus before it was developed is a valid proof or indication of the virus being created before the outbreak in China.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation provided by Clorox itself, stating that their products are effective against viruses similar to the 2019 coronavirus, but not claiming to have specifically targeted the 2019 strain before its discovery.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there is no evidence that the 2019 coronavirus was developed or created before the outbreak in China.
Understate: None of the biases listed in the expert's verdict can be categorized as understating.
Falters at times: None of the biases listed in the expert's verdict can be categorized as faltering at times.
